summary: The document is a memorandum from the Central Cover Staff (CCS) to the Deputy Director for Plans, dated 25 November 1968, addressing new allegations by Ramparts Magazine about 145 tax-exempt organizations suspected of CIA connections. It categorizes these organizations based on their known or suspected CIA associations, evaluates the potential impact of these allegations, and includes a request for 990-A tax forms to further investigate funding sources. The memorandum suggests that Ramparts' interest stems from publicly available information rather than an internal leak and concludes that no further action is needed as relevant CIA elements have been informed.
key_findings: 89 of the 145 organizations listed by Ramparts Magazine had CIA associations, with only two currently of operational interest.
42 organizations had former CIA ties not previously exposed, while 55 had no known CIA connections.
Three additional project organizations, not on Ramparts' list, were identified as vulnerable due to covert funding by unexposed foundations.
Ramparts' investigation likely relied on overt information and interviews, not an internal CIA leak.
No further action was deemed necessary as the responsible CIA elements were already aware of the findings.
Several organizations received legitimate funding from foundations like Harnischfeger and Old Dominion.
Six organizations had officers/directors linked to CIA projects.
A request for 990-A tax forms was made to explore funding and connections further.
There was a suggestion to collaborate with McGraw-Hill Publishing on a book about organizations cooperating with the CIA.
